abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Agricultural Services
            Producer Organizations Project for Senegal is a national
            agricultural program on rural activities, mainly in the
            field of agriculture and animal husbandry.  This
            environmental and social management framework gives an
            assessment of the environmental and social impacts, both
            beneficial and adverse that the project may entail, when
            implemented in whatever agro ecological area that may be
            concerned. Expected negative impacts associated with
            subprojects include: misuse of chemical pesticides and water
            pollution in the irrigation system; loss of pasturage for
            livestock and land degradation arising from overuse;
            clogging of the drainage system from stored materials, and
            interference with natural habitats if not ecosystem
            destruction; flooding; disease spread because of stagnant
            waters (including malaria and bilharzia) water contamination
            leading to dysentery and other diseases due to non-use of
            latrines and other unhygienic practices; conflicts over
            water usage; noise during blasting; erosion; soil
            salinization; the reduction of land able to be cultivated;
            lack of veterinary medicines; over-exploitation of forests;
            risk of contamination from pharmaceuticals improperly stored
            within households; environmental pollution from wastewater
            and solid waste from livestock; risk of marginalization of
            small producers due to market segmentation, the rise in the
            meat prices, infrastructure modernization and their
            maintenance costs, and unemployment of informal sector
            workers; loss of vegetal cover and increased erosion;
            lowering of the water table; and contamination due to
            pesticide use; air pollution and noxious odors;
            contamination of food products; and risk of fire, among
            other impacts. Mitigation measures may include: the rational
            use of pesticides, reserving spaces for foraging, restoring
            soil fertility, training farmers and farmer organizations to
            maintain flood works and in animal hygiene and veterinary
            techniques; latrine construction; conflict resolution used
            to control water usage; building of troughs and wells;
            installing of pumps far from residences; building irrigation
            canals for the dry season; replacing excavated material;
            providing compensation to displaced persons; using drainage
            works; replanting trees; integrated management of water
            resources; avoiding prolonged food storage; ensuring that
            imported animals are disease-free (have a certificate of
            health); encouraging traditional/local pastoral
            practices/indigenous knowledge and technical innovation, and
            improving traditional infrastructure; restoring the vegetal
            cover; establishing a waste management plan; promoting the
            use of organic fertilizer (manure); making selective site
            choices; wearing protective gear to avoid pesticide
            poisoning; avoiding the introduction of exotic species even
            if the risk is low; treating wastewater according to
            international norms; and raising sensitivity of sexually
            transmitted diseases among workers.
